normalised: Hey guys, how many times have you been binge-watching something on N A S A, maybe right when Virat Kohli is about to hit that winning six, and B A M! Power gone? Yeah, that's load shedding messing with your chai and chill time.

normalised: Load shedding, or planned power cuts as some fancy folks call it, is basically when the electric company deliberately switches off power to certain areas to prevent the entire system from collapsing. Think of it like this: Imagine auntyji trying to make biryani for the entire Sharma family gathering during Diwali. If she puts too much pressure on the gas stove all at once, the whole thing might conk out, right? Load shedding is kinda like that, but for the whole electricity grid.

normalised: Why does this happen, especially in India? Well, there are a bunch of reasons. Sometimes it's simply not enough power being generated to meet the demand. Think peak summer in Delhi when everyone’s A C is blasting full force. Other times, it’s due to problems with the power plants themselves – maybe a breakdown or maintenance work happening at the N T P C plant in Badarpur. Old infrastructure, especially in smaller towns like, say, near Patna, also contributes. Think rusty wires and outdated transformers that can't handle the load. And sometimes, shockingly, it's because of electricity theft, with people tapping into the grid illegally, overloading the system for everyone else. Chor bazaar electric style, not cool!
